author: pauld.9606
content: EVM384 minor update: Our gas cost estimates for pairings will be published soon. These estimates have required a lot of optimization work, which is being done now.

author: holiman
content: <@!301186049323958275> could you please make any necessary updates to 2930 to align things? I'll review and thumb it up

author: sky.cactus
content: <@!211091239112671234> https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/pull/3101/files is the minimum requirement.

author: axic3354
content:
<@!301186049323958275> <@!206016661470314496> couldn't the eth protocol support for the "wrapped legacy transactions" introduced earlier, not tied to a hardfork and not doing any of the other changes?

Let's say that "eth/67" means that EIP-2972 style transactions are accepted on the wire, but the wrapping is dropped in the client and nothing else changes. This means the transaction pool would support these transactions today.

And then when we get to the hardfork the other changes are rolled out.

author: sky.cactus
content: Not my personal preference for end-state, but getting to end-state requires more discussion it sounds like.

author: sky.cactus
content: <@!543900561460822016> Ah, you are right.  I think SSZ actually is used in receipts.  üò¢

author: sky.cactus
content: Not just SSZ-like.

author: holiman
content:
> Let's say that "eth/67"
A client supporing `eth/67` _must_ support `eth/66` and `eth/65` too

author: axic3354
content: I understand that, btw why cannot these versions be renamed?

author: axic3354
content: Are some clients supporting some of them already?

author: axic3354
content: I assume the problem is that the handshake has a "max version accepted" field.

author: holiman
content: I think no clients, maybe excepting trinity, supports `eth/66` (message-id)

author: holiman
content: I wouldn't want to wind up in a scenario where clients keep putting off `eth/65`, because that one reduces the network traffic _dramatically_

author: holiman
content: But yeah, we don't want to push everyone to implement it "now now" either

author: sky.cactus
content: <@!187490121698770945> Update to 2972 to remove legacy transactions from blocks.

author: axic3354
content: <@!689161464829050960> <@!415548822983278593> https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/pull/2751 and https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/pull/2934 for getting rid of selfdestruct. It would be nice see if this could be done üòâ

author: tkstanczak
content: I made a comment on Zoom chat - shall we consider that we can deliver 2930 without having 2718 (like we did inside 1559(

author: tkstanczak
content: then we have time to work on 2718

author: sky.cactus
content: I'm pretty against any transaction changes without 2718.

author: sky.cactus
content: Though, I don't actually get a vote for this sort of thing.  üòõ

author: tkstanczak
content: nobody does

author: tkstanczak
content: or you do

author: sky.cactus
content:
Re: Disclosure.
I'm against any kind of privileged list of participants that get advanced notice of things.  It reinforces centralization because it gives a competitive advantage to sufficiently large actors.

author: holiman
content: Yup, he Micah get's a vote

author: timbeiko
content:
FWIW, Infura mentioned in their postmortem _they_ are also against getting advance notice: 
> While we have a good line of communication between our two teams, we have never expected any preferential treatment or inside access to information. No exchange, no miner, no API provider should be treated differently than a single node runner.
https://blog.infura.io/infura-mainnet-outage-post-mortem-2020-11-11/amp/

author: holiman
content: Re advanced notice: It's also not crystal clear who should be on it. From a paranoid perspective: miners and downstream (alternative blockchains) might have incentives to cause chain splits on Ethereum mainnet. Rationally speaking

author: prestwich
content: I think that the Geth team and the EF can exercise good judgment wrt who is notified

author: prestwich
content: I see your point about incentives, but I would prefer if you didn't treat me as adversarial. I don't think I've done anything to warrant it üôÇ

author: sky.cactus
content: I don't treat **you** as adversarial, I actually like you very much!  I just don't like the idea of creating the infrastructure and process that creates an environment for capture and competitive advantages to big actors in the system.

author: timbeiko
content: I think those are two different points though!

author: holiman
content: <@!619357961923330051> I don't see you as an adversarial, and I'm not _that_ paranoid, I was just making a point that it's not crystal clear

author: sky.cactus
content: Classic example is Infura gets on the list (big enough), QuikNode does not (not big enough).

author: timbeiko
content: Yes, but for example, do you put ETC on the list? Are they adversarial?

author: timbeiko
content: Do you put an "Eth2 killer" who is building off a fork of geth?

author: sky.cactus
content: Probably not, despite ETC having strong incentives to be adversarial.  üòâ

author: holiman
content: I did confirm to you immediately what the 'sploit was. But the basis of trust is built upon interaction. We've been having some interaction, and I've built up a trust in you, personally. That does not extend to random "downstream projects" in general, though, and I'd confide things to you that I wouldn't want to send to some official list <@!619357961923330051>

author: prestwich
content: I don't think there ought to be an official list. A policy that allows you to exercise good judgment re: risks/benefits of notification would be great

author: prestwich
content: I appreciate you confirming the issue, btw. it saved us a lot of trouble and let us act quicker

author: prestwich
content: it's definitely a thorny issue, particularly with downstream projects. It's hard to balance the risk of disclosure vs potential to prevent harm to downstream users

author: prestwich
content: Protecting stability of Ethereum mainnet is clearly the most important thing to consider. But where the risk to Ethereum is minimal, protecting users of infrastructure providers and downstream projects should be considered too

author: prestwich
content: anyway, we're going to take this week as an opportunity to update our own security & disclosure policies üëç

author: sky.cactus
content: Sorry about that number change <@!211091239112671234>.  Fixed now if you want to review again.
